channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Philippine Leader Shifts Drug War to Officials, Meeting Resistance and Approval
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines, center, at a military hospital in Quezon City this month.
item.media:credit: Malacanang Photo Bureau, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: In what seemed to be a new phase of the effort, President Rodrigo Duterte took on judges and police generals, military officials and mayors, among others.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Philippines Talks of Barring Donald Trump for Calling It a ‘Terrorist Nation’
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at a campaign rally in Portland, Me., last week. “We are letting people come in from terrorist nations that shouldn’t be allowed because you can’t vet them,” he said.
item.media:credit: Brendan Bullock for The New York Times
item.description: After the candidate said the country was among those sending “animals” to the United States, a Philippine lawmaker urged that Mr. Trump be denied entry.
item.dc:creator: J. R. ALIBUTUD

item.title: Thai Leader Links Attacks on Tourist Sites to Constitution Change
item.media:description: A man on Friday walked past the site of a bombing and arson attack on Bang Niang market in the Takua Pa district of Thailand.
item.description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, the junta chief and prime minister, hinted that the bombers were “bad people” opposed to a new Constitution.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Torrential Rains Strand Wayward Indian Elephant in Bangladesh
item.media:description: A tranquilized wild elephant lies on the ground Thursday after being pulled from a pond by Bangladesh forest officials and villagers.
item.description: The four-and-a-half-ton animal was separated from its herd in northeast India and carried downstream to Bangladesh in June.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: In Syria, Battles for Aleppo Seem as Endless as the War Itself
item.media:description: Smoke rising last month over Aleppo, Syria, from tires burned to decrease the visibility of pilots from the Assad government and Russian forces.
item.media:credit: Beha el Halebi/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: The city has been seen as a crucial battleground as pro-Assad forces and rebel fighters have each won, then lost, battles there.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Ben-Gurion on Israel, Peace and Back Pain: A Lost Interview Is Brought to Life
item.media:description: The first prime minister of Israel, David Ben-Gurion, at his home in 1972 on the eve of his 86th birthday.
item.description: In a recently rediscovered interview, David Ben-Gurion spoke of state-building, the biblical prophets that guided him and Israel’s quest for security.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Police in South Africa Struggle to Gain Trust After Apartheid
item.media:description: Col. Nhluvuko Zondi became the Alexandra police station’s first black female commander last year. She said relations with the public had improved over the years.
item.description: Forces now mirror a largely black population, but are seen by many as not focused on keeping it safe as killings of and by officers occur at higher rates than in the United States.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Polio Response in Africa to Be Fast, Difficult and Possibly Dangerous
item.media:description: Children waiting to receive polio vaccine in Kawo Kano, Nigeria, in 2014. The country has reported the first two cases of polio after more than two years.
item.description: Stopping the disease in Africa, where two new cases have just been found, is crucial to the high-stakes effort to eradicate it from the world.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: ‘A Generation Is Protesting’ in Ethiopia, Long a U.S. Ally
item.description: Protesters in a repressive nation focus on issues like land use and the governing party’s stranglehold on power.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Aid and Attention Dwindling, Migrant Crisis Intensifies in Greece
item.media:description: A Syrian refugee surrounded by abandoned tents and garbage on Thursday at Nea Kavala, a camp in northern Greece.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: Tens of thousands of asylum seekers are languishing in camps, with more trickling in, and neither Western and Northern Europe nor Turkey are doing much to help.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Q & A: How a Priest Made the Case for Mother Teresa’s Sainthood
item.media:description: The Rev. Brian Kolodiejchuk last week in Rome at the residence of the Missionaries of Charity Fathers, his order, which was founded by Mother Teresa. He has been the postulator, or promoter for her case for sainthood.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: In this Q. and A., the Rev. Brian Kolodiejchuk, the editor of a book on Mother Teresa and a member of an order she founded, tells of the process leading to her canonization.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: What in the World: A Tough Sell, Even in Russia: Ivan the Not-So-Terrible
item.media:description: Ivan the Terrible And His Son Ivan, November 16th 1581 by Ilya Repin
item.description: A Russian governor plans to erect a statue to honor the notorious czar, but many in his region are not impressed.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: U.S. Strike Said to Kill ISIS Chief of Afghanistan-Pakistan Region
item.description: The Pentagon said Hafiz Saeed Khan, the leader of the Islamic State’s Afghanistan-Pakistan branch, was killed in an operation on July 26.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Shah Rukh Khan, ‘King of Bollywood,’ Was Detained at a U.S. Airport for the Third Time
item.media:description: Bollywood actor Shah Rukh Khan earlier this year.
item.description: “Whenever I start feeling too arrogant about myself, I always take a trip to America,” said Mr. Khan, the last time he was held at an American airport.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Cannes, Citing Security Risks, Bans Full-Body ‘Burkinis’ From Its Beaches
item.media:description: A public beach in Cannes, France. Security along the French Riviera and in much of the country has been increased in light of recent terrorist attacks.
item.description: A temporary decree in the French city prohibits people in attire that is not “respectful of good morals and secularism” from swimming in public areas.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Trillions in Murky Investments Could Rock China’s Economy
item.media:description: Neighborhoods like Guangfuli, in Shanghai, have been remade in China's development boom. Now real estate is faltering, posing a threat to barely regulated financial products whose investors may have little idea of their exposure.
item.description: Long on promises and short on details, investments known as wealth management products have drawn a flood of money — and pose a big risk.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Father’s Death Sets Off a Quest to Delve Into China’s Soul
item.media:description: Yang Weidong has been documenting China through a series of video interviews.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: Yang Weidong became consumed with one burning desire: to understand how China ended up with its authoritarian political and social system.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Botched Restoration of Fresco in Spain Inspires a Comic Opera
item.media:description: The altered “Ecce Homo” fresco, by the painter Elías García Martínez, on display in Borja, Spain, in 2012.
item.description: Two Americans wrote the work, “Behold the Man,” which tells how amateurish repairs to a painting of Jesus in 2012 brought a tourist bonanza to a struggling town.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Memo From Russia: Putin Dismisses Sergei Ivanov, a Longtime Ally, as Chief of Staff
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, with Sergei B. Ivanov, left, and Anton E. Vaino, in Moscow on Friday. Mr. Putin appointed Mr. Vaino chief of staff, replacing Mr. Ivanov, a trusted aide of four decades.
item.description: The firing of Sergei B. Ivanov was the latest in a series that has ushered out an older layer of Putin allies and replaced them with younger loyalists.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Sinosphere: More Openly Gay Olympians Than Ever, but No Chinese Among Them
item.media:description: Brittney Griner of the United States women’s basketball team, one of the openly gay athletes competing in the 2016 Olympics, during a game against Spain on Monday.
item.description: The absence of Chinese athletes “shows that the environment isn’t here for sexual minorities to come out yet,” a spokesman for an advocacy group said.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: U.N. Bolsters Peacekeeping in South Sudan Despite Government’s Objections
item.media:description: Soldiers with the United Nations Mission in South Sudan in Juba last month. United Nations soldiers and aid workers have been repeatedly harassed and attacked, and in some cases killed.
item.media:credit: Eric Kanalstein/U.N. Mission in Sudan, via Associated Press
item.description: The resolution, approved in an 11-to-0 vote, represents a robust action by the Security Council, invoking its rarely used coercive power.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Snapchat Finds Itself on the Wrong Side of a Racial Lens. Again.
item.media:description: Snapchat says this filter is inspired by anime, but some observers say it’s racially insensitive.
item.description: A lens that gave users slanted eyes was criticized as an Asian caricature. It wasn’t the first time the app has faced a backlash.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: ‘The Girl From Ipanema’ Goes Walking Again, With Gisele Bündchen’s Help
item.media:description: Heloísa Pinheiro in 2012. She was the muse for “The Girl From Ipanema.”
item.description: Thanks to the supermodel’s strut during the opening ceremony of the Rio Olympics, the 1963 bossa nova tune has found new life.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Opinion: How the Most Dangerous Place on Earth Got Safer
item.media:description: Children play in an abandoned structure by a soccer field in the Rivera Hernández neighborhood in San Pedro Sula, Honduras. Gangs used to frequent this building — a girl walking home from high school was kidnapped by gang members and then brought here and raped two years ago — and the soccer field used to be a place to bury bodies.
item.media:credit: Katie Orlinsky for The New York Times
item.description: Programs funded by the United States are helping transform Honduras. Who says American power is dead?
item.dc:creator: SONIA NAZARIO

item.title: Editorial: Thailand’s Power-Hungry Generals
item.media:description: Thai soldiers cast their vote in Bangkok last Sunday.
item.description: Voters approved a new Constitution they were barred from debating, which gives the country’s military sweeping powers.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For Migrants, an Olympic Village in Ruins
item.description: Greece is housing some 2,000 Afghan and other migrants in crumbling stadiums left over from the Games of 2004. The biggest complaint: boredom.
item.dc:creator: DOVE BARBANEL
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Afghanistan Is in Chaos. Is That What Hamid Karzai Wants?
item.media:description: Hamid Karzai, the former president of Afghanistan, at his compound in Kabul last month.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Critics say the former president is working from the wings to destabilize his successor’s government. He says he has no interest in returning to power.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
